repnme.cdata!: Brazil - Minas Gerais Forestry Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Minas Gerais Forestry Development
            Project in Brazil. The project is rated satisfactory overall
            because it achieved most of its objectives. This project has
            produced many important lessons that should be directly
            applicable to the design of similar environmental protection
            and natural resource management projects in other states of
            Brazil as well as in other Latin American countries. Key
            lessons learned includes: 1) Predicting the demand for
            credit proved difficult under the project, largely because
            of economic uncertainty; 2) Concerning the development of
            new protected areas, the project has clearly demonstrated
            the importance of: (i) prioritizing area development, taking
            into account local interest and participation, as well as
            biodiversity/ecosystem representation; (ii) having fallback
            options in the phasing of developments in new protected
            areas so as not to be hamstrung by the inevitable
            bureaucratic delays to the legal transfer of the land to the
            state, required for works to begin; and (iii) preparing and
            updating participatory management plans prior to initiating
            developments in new parks; 3) This project clearly
            demonstrates the value of mid-term reviews; 4) The
            project's credit line suffered from an
            over-concentration of borrowers; 5) The project has
            demonstrated that project performance is highly dependent on
            the quality of local management and the political weight it
            carries; 6) The project has shown that high quality
            technical assistance contributed greatly to implementation performance.

repnme.cdata!: Brazil - Minas Gerais Forestry Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Since Minas Gerais' natural
            resource base of forests is being depleted, jeopardizing
            major industries, the Minas Gerais Forestry Development
            Project aims to increase industrial wood production, reduce
            degradation of the native forests, and improve environmental
            protection.  To that end, the project aims to finance:  (a)
            the establishment of up to 165,000 ha of forest plantations
            and the building of charcoal manufacturing kilns and related
            infrastructure through a line of credit; (b) the planting of
            about 40,000 ha of woodlots on small and medium-sized farms;
            and (c) staff, equipment and consulting services for
            forestry conservation.  Finally, the project seeks to
            provide (d) institutional development to strengthen the
            State Forestry Institute (IEC); and (e) project evaluation.

docna.cdata!: Brazil - Minas Gerais Forestry Development Project
